thread.title: No respite: Monday storm may bring up to 18 inches - The Boston Globe
thread.title_full: No respite: Monday storm may bring up to 18 inches - The Boston Globe

title: No respite: Monday storm may bring up to 18 inches - The Boston Globe
text:
Some areas in Eastern Massachusetts received more than 4 inches in last night’s snowfall. 
Parts of the Commonwealth that lie north of the Connecticut and Rhode Island borders could see accumulation between 8 and 12 inches, while the northeastern section of the state is expected to get between 12 and 18 inches, according to the weather service. Coastal parts of Plymouth County could see between 6 and 10 inches, according to the service. 
Snow is expected to turn to rain for several hours late Sunday night into Monday morning, before dropping temperatures bring snow back to the region. Advertisement 
“It should be snow by 4 a.m. Monday, so if the temperatures do drop enough, then there is potential for freezing if there’s water on the roads,” Correia said. 
Snowfall is expected to be the heaviest Monday morning, the statement said. Combined with blowing and drifting snow, that could reduce visibility to as little as a quarter mile. 
Strong winds could also threaten the area midday Monday with gusts of up to 70 mph on the Cape and Islands creating a potential for power outages, coastal flooding, and beach erosion, Massachusetts Emergency Management Agency said in a statement. Inland and coast areas could see wind speeds of 25 mph and 45 mph, respectively. National Weather Service. 
The storm will follow a frigid Saturday, where many awoke in the morning to find a fresh covering of overnight snow, cloudy skies, and temperatures below freezing. 
About 3 inches of snow fell on Boston overnight, Correia said. That’s on top of the nearly 11 inches that blanketed Boston during the first blizzard to hit the city since 2015 , which hit the city Thursday. 
The Cape and Islands received just an inch of new snow, while north of Boston saw about 2.5 inches. 
Saturday’s temperatures are expected to top out at 37 degrees, with winds at a light 10 miles per hour, and a low of 25 degrees. 
Correia said the snow should be over for the day but she warned that Saturday night could bring freezing rain, and with it, black ice. 
“Be careful — tonight especially ” she said. Aimee Ortiz of the Globe staff contributed to this report. Amanda Hoover can be reached at . Loading comments...
